Situation1: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: I sat at my kitchen table, laptop open, reviewing the schedule for the national continuing education program. The sessions were crucial—new guidelines on diabetes management, updates on drug interactions, all essential for my work as a pharmacist. My license depended on staying current, and my patients trusted me to know the latest. But as I scanned the agenda, my heart sank. The most important workshops were scheduled for Sunday mornings, the same time as church service. I hadn’t been to worship in weeks, always telling myself I’d go when time allowed. My church community expected me to be present, to worship together, to serve and grow in faith. I missed the sense of belonging, the peace I felt singing hymns and praying with others. Now, I felt torn—my profession demanded my attention, but so did my faith. I stared at the calendar, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which path to choose.
